Award.AwardTitle: Early Childhood Education in the Context of Mathematics, Science, and Literacy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Mathematics, Science, and Literacy (MSL) curriculum project is using empirically-tested mathematics and science programs and research-based approaches to develop a six module interdisciplinary curriculum for pre-K students. Mathematics and science content is included with literacy/language and social-emotional development. The curriculum is being designed to counter the frequent situation of devoting most pre-school instructional time to literacy by having activities that join literacy with mathematics and science. The project is housed at the University of Buffalo, but also has sites at Rutgers University New Brunswick and Michigan State University. A detailed process, a curriculum development framework that has been used to develop prior curriculum materials is being used for developing the MSL curriculum. The design of the materials is giving strong attention to being viable for at-risk students.

The MSL materials are research-based and incorporate learning trajectories developed from prior work. The materials are being developed in the first two years of the project and piloted by a four teachers at each of the three sites. In the third year of the four year project, the materials will be piloted by four different teachers at each of the three sites. Formative evaluation data are being used to revise the materials. Pretests and posttests in each of the three content areas are being used to measure improved learning. An external evaluator is verifying the analyses of data and that valid conclusions are being made. The development effort includes attending to the professional development needs of teachers who will be using the six module pre-K curriculum and teachers who will have students who have completed the curriculum.

The main deliverable will be the research-based six module curriculum for pre-K mathematics, science, and literacy. In addition, a detailed formative evaluation of the curriculum's creation and implementation is being produced along with a detailed description and evaluation of the curriculum model used. A publisher has indicated interest in publishing the materials and is interacting with the developers throughout the process. There is a potential that the interdisciplinary curriculum will be widely used. The curriculum is being designed using the most current learning trajectories with the expectations that these will particularly helpful for at risk students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Connect 4 Learning (C4L) is an interdisciplinary curriculum that weaves together mathematics, science, literacy, and social-emotional learning to ensure that each subject is addressed meaningfully and comprehensively.

C4L features six curriculum units that are focused on supporting children's development of ten comprehensive cognitive processes:

  1. Communicating and representing,
  2. Cooperating,
  3. Comparing and Classifying,
  4. Creating, Imagining and innovating;
  5. Asking questions and seeking new information;
  6. Observing; 
  7. Persisting, attending and self-regulation;
  8. Reasoning and problem solving;
  9. Making sense;
  10. Using tools strategically.

Learning in each of the four domains follows a continuum throughout the year. There are activities designed to address concepts in each domain as well as activities that develop content in two or more domains. Each unit has a product that requires children to apply their knowledge. 

In developing C4L, we synthesized empirically-tested programs and approaches to learning in the four domains. The curriculum was designed to counter the frequent situation of devoting most pre-K instructional time to literacy and/or social emotional development by having activities that merge literacy and social emotional development with mathematics and science. The detailed processes of a curriculum research-and-development framework guided C4L’s development. The design of the materials gave strong attention to being viable for supporting at-risk students.

The C4L approach addresses concerns of educators that they do not have time to teach math and science because of other requirements, especially teaching literacy skills. C4L begins with learning sequences in science and mathematics topics, which are grounded in research-based learning trajectories and developmental pathways. The curriculum draws connections between mathematics and science, but allows each to retain its core structures. Literacy and language and social emotional skills are integrated as natural components of the mathematics and science activities, with the goal of strengthening all of these. Finally, the C4L curriculum focuses specifically on literacy and social emotional skills, when appropriate. For example, there is a dedicated time for developing phonological awareness and letter-sound knowledge. The rest of the day provides opportunities to reinforce and extend these skills, such as through transition activities the develop phonological awareness and opportunities to write while engaged in science investigations. Similarly, our approach to social emotional development includes lessons on specific topics such as particular emotions and social problem-solving strategies. This approach is based on the assumption that teachers can promote important social skills and emotional competencies throughout the day, including the provision of developmentally appropriate and appropriately challenging activities that cut across subject areas.

 A consistent approach is used to teaching in each domain.

  • Concern with the tools available (e.g., math manipulatives, utensils and surfaces for writing and drawing, materials for science)
  • Responsive teaching. Strategies are informed and adjusted based on children’s responses.
  • An iterative learning cycle of experience, reflection, explicit explanation, guided practice, independent practice and synthesis.
  • A project-based approach, in which children work toward a larger goal, such as growing a garden, throughout a unit.

In each unit, there is a common topic across disciplines. Content is contextualized within the same topic in each domain. For example, in a garden unit, mathematics includes counting seeds, measuring plant growth, and creating a garden mural from shapes; science includes sprouting plants, raising worms, learning about the needs of living things, and learning where food comes from; literacy includes reading informational texts and classic stories about gardens and plants, keeping a science journal about growing radishes, and writing invitations to a garden party; and social emotional includes the concept of working together and collaborating to grow a garden.

 Many lessons and learning experiences simultaneously address objectives from different disciplines. For example, a lesson on measuring and recording growth of plants addresses a social emotional objective (learn to work collaboratively to solve a problem), science objective (learn that living things grow over time), a mathematics objective (learn to compose and decompose geometric shapes), and a literacy objective (use drawing and writing to record information). In another unit, children design alphabet letters (literacy), study the nature of materials, such as rigid and non-rigid (science and engineering) and the geometric forms (math), using “think-pair-share” and other collaborative strategies (social-emotional). 

The materials were pilot tested in several classrooms across several sites as the curriculum went through multiple revisions and refinements. Final results showed gains in mathematics, science, and literacy and a decrease in problem behaviors.
